meta.subject: Zambian Languages
meta.philosophy:
The focus of teaching Literacy and Language in Zambian Languages from Grade 1 to 3 is to develop the learners’ basic reading and writing skills as well as to enhance their listening and speaking skills. Thus, the main components of the syllabus are:
• Listening and speaking
• Reading
• Vocabulary
• Comprehension
• Writing
These components will enhance the development of listening, speaking, reading and writing skills. The competences acquired at this level will prepare learners for learning at subsequent levels.
Although the components are presented separately in this syllabus, teachers are required to integrate them at lesson delivery. This entails that at preparation stage the syllabus should be broken down into schemes of work and weekly forecast which will contain these components – listening and speaking, reading, vocabulary, comprehension and writing.
meta.competence_learning:
The teaching of Literacy and Language will follow Constructivist principles. This is where the teacher provides learners with experiences that allow them to hypothesise, predict, manipulate objects, pose questions, research, investigate, imagine, and invent. It will make use of systematic synthetic phonics, which involves the explicit teaching of the following key literacy skills; phonological and phonemic awareness, phonics, vocabulary, reading, comprehension and writing skills. In synthetic phonics, learners are taught letter sounds that they blend to be able to read as opposed to analytic phonics where learners are taught to recognise whole words by sight, and later to break down the word into the smaller units.
Generally, lesson delivery should follow the Gradual Release Model (GRM), where the teacher starts by demonstrating the activity, then doing the activity with the learners and finally learners doing the activity independently. Furthermore, a variety of teaching techniques should be employed in order to meet different learning needs of learners.

specific_outcomes: Use complete sentences to communicate information
Ask relevant questions to get better understanding and knowledge
Read aloud syllables formed by three or more consonant clusters
Read words of increasing number of syllables
Draw inferences from the information they have heard.
Deduce the meaning of unfamiliar grade level words
Express the main idea of the information they have listened to.
Link their own life experiences to what they listen to
Provide explicitly stated information in a given grade level text
Identify the main idea in a story.
Recall order of events in a text
Make predictions based on given information
Link their own life experiences to what they read
Write words of increasing number of syllables legibly in manuscript form
Use the main punctuation marks (capital letters, full stop, comma and question mark).
Compose and write a short fiction story of 4 to 6 sentences.
Compose and write a short exposition
